awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The leaky rake to solid plate transition on flow through biological filtering structures
awd_abstract_narration:
Numerous small organisms that swim, fly, smell, or feed in flow rely on branched, bristled and hairy structures that are significant to biological and biomedical applications. The movement and orientation of such bristled layers can change the behavior of the air or water flow through them such that they may act as either solid plates or leaky rakes. Understanding how animals creatively take advantage of this type of flow transition could inform the design of filters and sampling devices. Although such flows have been studied in many systems, predictive mathematical models of the leaky rake to solid plate transition remain unavailable. The goal of this project is to reveal the physical mechanisms behind this transition through mathematical modeling and experimentation. The theoretical models developed could find applications in biomedical problems such as the flow of lymph and blood through porous tissues and vascular protective layers. In terms of education and outreach, students will be trained at the interface of engineering, mathematics, and biology through interdisciplinary courses, field research, and multidisciplinary group meetings. Diverse students will be recruited through the Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (LSAMP).

This research will elucidate the fundamental fluid dynamics of biological and bioinspired filtering arrays operating at the mesoscale, where inertial and viscous forces are nearly balanced. It will also reveal the fundamental physics of particle capture and exchange when advection and diffusion are nearly balanced. Two types of marine invertebrates will be examined: 1) upside-down jellyfish that drive flow through 3D bristled oral arms, and 2) sea fans that are branched into approximately 2D sheets. Modeling the leaky-to-solid transition is challenging due to the need to simultaneously resolve small-scale flow around micron-scale structures and bulk flow around centimeter-scale arrays. New mathematical models, informed by experiments, will be developed to describe the effective porosity of flexible filtering layers. Particle capture rates and concentration profiles around mesoscale filtering arrays will be quantified experimentally in organisms and physical models. Further details of chemical exchange will be resolved numerically using the immersed boundary method. In terms of biology, these organisms represent one of many examples where particle capture and nutrient uptake occur in mesoscale bristled arrays. Revealing how this strategy is advantageous contributes directly to the NSF Rules of Life. In terms of bioinspired design, these systems exhibit inherently multiscale solutions for filtering and exchange that will provide new insights into the bioinspired design of filtering structures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The research conducted in this project revealed the dynamic interactions between marine organisms and their fluid environments as well as new phenomena in fundamental fluid mechanics. In the first project, state-of-the art techniques, including tomographic particle image velocimetry and immersed boundary simulations, revealed the complex flow patterns generated by upside down jellyfish as they filter feed. The elaborate structures of these jellyfish’s oral arms are tuned to enhance the capture of prey, while the presence of the substrate augments feeding and nutrient exchange. In the second study, the overall structures of colonial soft coral gorgonians were found to be well-tuned to capture prey on a typical day while minimizing drag to resist breakage during strong storms. In particular, these corals produce downstream eddies that allow their polyps to capture prey in slow flows. In strong flows, the branched colony is leaky, which minimizes the drag experienced. In another soft coral species, a 3D numerical model of an actively pulsing polyp was developed. This model showed that the coral tentacles’ emergent pulses, determined by its material properties and neurobiology, create a blowing jet with a slow mixing zone over the tentacles. This allows new fluid to be sampled during each pulse. The neuromuscular design is also optimized for energy efficiency. These findings not only advance our understanding of marine biomechanics but also have potential applications in the design of bio-inspired devices.

 

The project significantly contributed to the development of interdisciplinary education in bio-mathematics, bioengineering, and biological fluid dynamics, particularly aimed at students from engineering and the biological sciences. PI Miller has led numerous workshops and tutorials focusing on fluid-organism interactions and aquatic locomotion. Through her involvement with the NSF-funded UCI Center for Integrative Movement Sciences, she has contributed significantly to the dissemination of knowledge for graduate students interested in computational fluid dynamics. The research group is also responsible for the creation and maintenance of various software libraries for simulating biological flows and the movement of prey. All tools are freely available through GitHub, are actively used in course projects and undergraduate research. Moreover, Miller’s ongoing tutorial series on the immersed boundary method provides valuable learning resources for a wide range of academics, from junior faculty to undergraduates.  PI Miller also developed an upper-level course in mathematical modeling, integrating practical elements like 3D printing for flow visualization and numerical simulation. Lessons learned from this course and sample projects are currently being distributed through presentations and publications.

 


Last Modified: 12/27/2023
Modified by: Laura A Miller

Image
  • Dye visualization of flow through a gorgonian with polyps extended (top) and retracted (bottom). Immersed boundary simulations of flow past polyps extended from an idealized branch of the gorgonian. The configuration of the polyps drastically changes the flow.
    Laura Miller, Brad Gemmell, Matea Santiago
    Creative Commons
    Laura A Miller
    The effect of polyps on flows around gorgonians
